newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan group wants Asian counter-measure to OPEC.
newsitem.headline: Japan group wants Asian counter-measure to OPEC.

text.p: An Asian OPEC? Well, not exactly.
But an influential Japanese business group is pushing for an Asian oil cartel that would oversee negotiations with Middle Eastern oil producing countries.
Among other things, such a cartel would use the collective buying power of Asia's booming economies to secure better oil price terms and supply security guarantees from the world's biggest producers.

"In essence, the cartel would serve as a counter-measure to big producers, an organisation in the image of OPEC which would serve Asia's oil-consuming countries," said an official from the Japan Association of Corporate Executives (Keizai Doyukai).

The business group has proposed the idea in a report which it submitted to Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs early last month. It is awaiting a response.
According to the study, the body should operate under the auspices of the 18-member Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum and be based in Tokyo.
It said huge growth in oil demand in Asia meant regional players should hold talks aimed at avoiding conflicts of interests in oil purchases.
At the underbelly of the argument lies a changing balance of power among Asia's major oil importers, analysts said.

"There's a lot more competition on the demand side in Asia than there was ten years ago," said Paul Horsnell, head of studies in Asia/Middle East relations at Britain's Oxford Institute of Energy Economics.
He said some APEC members, like the United States, would be against such a cartel, but it would benefit Asia's tiger economies, and especially Japan, the region's largest importer.
"(South) Korean demand has quadrupled to more than two million barrels per day, and China is on the verge of huge growth in imports," Horsnell said.
"Together with Japan, that represents a lot of new competition which would spur prices higher," he said.
Some industry participants consider the cartel's chances unfavourable at best.
"This is not something Middle East producers are going to take seriously at this point," said an official from Iran's state National Iranian Oil Company.
But the cartel's Japanese proponents are more optimistic.

"We are eager to hear the response of the government ministries, but obviously the final approval of such a process would have to come from the member countries of APEC," the Keizai Doyukai official said.
He emphasised that the cartel would focus on negotiations with strictly Middle Eastern oil producers, not all of OPEC.

In addition to Iran, Iraq, Kuwait, Libya, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, and the United Arab Emirates, the eleven-member Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) includes Indonesia, Venezuela, Algeria, Nigeria.

APEC groups Australia, Brunei, Canada, Chile, China, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, Mexico, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, the Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Taiwan, Thailand and the United States.
